712471f-a.text:
(1)
151-141 East 38th Street, north side, between Third and Lexington
Avenues, showing an old stable at No. 149.
July 244, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
A view only of No. 149.
July 24, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
A more extensive view westward. Note the construction of a
new apartment house (No. 137 East 38th Street).
April 8, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

708062f-a.text:
Gypsies at S.W. corner of Third Avenue and 38th Street. News Building
in background.
P.L. Sperr, Photographer.

October 6,1933.

712470f-a.text:
152 East 38th Street, south side, between Third and Lexington Aves.
January 6, 1935.
P. L. Soerr.

708061f-a.text:
Third Avenue, west side, south from E. 38th Street as viewed from the easterly side of this thoroughfare.
January 7, 1939
Somach Photo Service
New York City Tunnel Authority

712465f-a.text:
E. 38th Street, east from Third Avenue. At the left is the Quaker House (No 201) a renovated (1937) former tenement. The Third Avenue buildings en the right bear No's 577 - 5 and 3; the latter being the Pet Shop.
January 7, 1939
Somach Photo Service
New York City Tunnel Authority

712466f-a.text:
E. 38th Street, north side, east from Third Avenue. At the left is the Quaker House (No. 201 E.) a renovated former tenement building. East of the same are garages, loft buildings and the brewery of J. C. G. Hupfel. Beyond the latter (across Second Avenue) appears the 16 story apartment structure, No. 301
E. 38th Street.
January 8, 1939
Somach Photo Service
New York City Tunnel Authority

712468f-a.text:
E. 38th Street, north side, east from (No. 215, left) a point to the east of Third Avenue and towards the East River. Hupfels Brewery extends thru this block to E. 39th Street.
January 7, 1939
Soach Photo Service
New York City Tunnel Authority

712472f-a.text:
#149 East 38th Street, north side between Third and Lexington Avenue showing the Ornate facade of an old stable.

P.L.Speer.
NO REPRODUCTION.           May 27, 1939.

708063f-a.text: Third Ave. looking North from 38th street.

3rd Avenue. View of Building looms in

Second and Third Avenue.
April 11, 1940.

Third Avenues. Demolition for Road.
